Gladed terrain.

Pit_Observation.activities: We snowmobiled slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Wind event 12/11 to 12/12, approx 17 hours overnight and morning of sustained 20-30 mph winds with gusts to 80 mph, near and above treeline. Heavy wind effect in exposed areas as well as hard wind slabs in lower angle moraine concavities. Easy to propagate wind slabs in column test but could not find any slabs on slopes steeper than 25-30 degrees. Most loose snow sublimated off mountain. Many exposed areas scoured to rock. No recent avalanches or signs of instability.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Faceted snow that developed during the November dry period reside in the bottom 35 centimeters of the snowpack and contain 3.65 inches (91 mm) of snow water equivalent. The slab and new snow above contained 5.5 inches (138 mm) of SWE.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: The future seems dire for this snow pack, but low-angle grass/sagebrush slopes are becoming rideable. Transport going on today at all elevations on this side of the pass with winds from NW.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Pit located just below WY22 overflow parking lot, down hill from lower twin slide in an area that had been skied. Ski tracks on slope; Snowmobile tracks on slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: NSF's at surface shouldn't be a problem unless high pressure continues. Facets at the ground have adjusted to the load of the slab on top. Obvious signs of instability are isolated. This area is covered in snowmobile and ski tracks and no avalanches. Unsure if some slopes avalanched during storms at T-giving and first part of Dec.
Snowpack rapidly becoming faceted with to 10 to 20 cms very loose and sugary

Pit_Observation.activities: We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Dug near the top of Nitwits, 20 yards below and skier's left of the standard entrance. This part of the slope likely did not release during the November 25th avalanche cycle whereas further down (mid slope and skiers left) did release after that loading event. Structure is relatively poor yet stability is relatively good right now. Phil dug a hasty pit further down near the suspected location of the November 25th crown and got an ECTX result.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Previous NE wind scoured down to 11/27 rain crust. 4mm surface hoar overnight almost attached to surface of semi-breakable crust. Ski pen only 2cm but boot pen 41cm. Pit_Observation.activities: Poor pit location

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: The basal facet layer is so thin, in most locations it's not continuous over the terrain, broken by rocks and vegetation. I think there are only isolated places, with smooth ground like rock slabs or grass, where you could connect enough snow for a slide to fail on the depth hoar.

Some plates observed near the recent new snow and old snow interface. Snowpack tests and informal observations did not show weakness at this interface. Surface hoar is widespread at all elevation ranges-some surface hoar was destroyed mid day with full sun on southerly aspects.

Pit_Observation.activities: We skied slope
Collapsing, widespread; Cracking; Instability rapidly rising; Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Quincy bowl is located just beyond the Daly Chutes at Deer Valley and is accessed by Empire Pass. While traveling on flat terrain I experienced a large, resounding collapse that. I skied a very low angle short shot and traveled out of the area on an old skin track that travels below a 10-15 degrees slope. While traveling on the old skin track I experienced more large collapses and saw some cracking on the steeper parts of that slope. Definitely was hair raising to watch some folks ski the nearby steeper terrain to the West, however they did not trigger anything. John Haney was also putting in some laps and for what it's worth said the skiing wasn't very good but still put in about 30 laps!
Off the peak at Powder King. Went to go derime the weather station. Near TL with well spaced 1-2 m trees, with thicker timber 75 m downslope.
Off the peak at Powder King. Went to go derime the weather station. Near TL with well spaced 1-2 m trees, with thicker timber 75 m downslope.
Tour objective: Dig pit and low angle pow turns. Began tour with 4/8 covered sky and ended with 8/8. In search of leeward persistent weak layers, and rain layer.
